revision.comment: "Used to" isn't needed, as no one could possibly think they still work there 66 years later.
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Use British English|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox television | show_name = The Bletchley Circle | image = The Bletchley Circle titlecard.jpg | caption = | alt = Series title in front of a Bombe electromechanical device | show_name_2 = | genre = | creator = | developer = | writer = [[Guy Burt]] | director = [[Andy De Emmony]]
Jamie Payne
Sarah Harding | creative_director = | presenter = | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Anna Maxwell Martin]] * [[Rachael Stirling]] * [[Sophie Rundle]] * [[Julie Graham]] * [[Hattie Morahan]] }} | judges = | voices = | narrated = | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | composer = Nick Green | country = United Kingdom | language = English | num_series = 2 | num_episodes = 7 | list_episodes = #Episode list | executive_producer = Simon Heath | producer = Jake Lushington | editor = | location = | cinematography = John Pardue | camera = | runtime = 45 minutes | company = [[World Productions]] | distributor = Kew Media | channel = [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_run = | first_aired = {{Start date|2012|9|6|df=yes}} | last_aired = {{End date|2014|1|27|df=y}} | preceded_by = | related = | website = | website_title = | production_website = https://www.world-productions.com/productions/bletchey-circle | followed_by = [[The Bletchley Circle: San Francisco]] }} '''''The Bletchley Circle''''' is a television mystery drama [[miniseries]], set in 1952–53, about four women who worked as [[Cryptanalysis|codebreakers]] at [[Bletchley Park]]. Dissatisfied with the officials' failure to investigate complex crimes, the women join to investigate for themselves.{{cite web|title=ITV press release|url=http://www.itv.com/presscentre/pressreleases/programmepressreleases/thebletchleycircle/default.html|publisher=[[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]|accessdate=7 January 2013}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The first series of the miniseries, produced for [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]], was originally shown in the UK in 2012 and premiered in the U.S. in April 2013, on [[PBS]].{{cite web| title= TV Review: ''The Bletchley Circle''| publisher= [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]| date= 17 April 2013| url= https://variety.com/2013/tv/reviews/tv-review-the-bletchley-circle-1200369763/| accessdate= 22 April 2013}} A second series was broadcast on ITV in January 2014 and on PBS in April 2014.{{cite web|title=PBS press release|url=https://www.pbs.org/about/news/archive/2013/winter-spring-season-programming/|publisher=[[PBS]]|accessdate=12 March 2014}} Both series were later aired by Australia's [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC TV]].{{cite book|url=http://www.abc.net.au/tv/programs/bletchley-circle/ |title=The Bletchley Circle|publisher= [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC TV]]|date= September 2014}} The series was distributed worldwide by Kew Media. {{Cite web|url=https://www.world-productions.com/productions/bletchey-circle|title=The Bletchey Circle - World Productions|last=Productions|first=World|website=World Productions|language=en|access-date=2018-09-03}} The programme was not renewed for a third series.{{cite web|last=Taylor|first=Francis|title=Digital spy|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a564880/the-bletchley-circle-axed-by-itv.html#~oBFPYjEHxpTNOR|accessdate=17 April 2014}} In 2018 a spinoff series titled ''[[The Bletchley Circle: San Francisco]]'' was announced by [[BritBox]].https://renewcanceltv.com/bletchley-circle-spinoff-series-coming-britbox-2018/ == Plot == Susan Gray, Millie, Lucy, and Jean work together at [[Bletchley Park]] to decipher [[Bletchley Park#German signals|German military codes]] for the British military, during [[World War II]]. After a brief introduction of the four women at Bletchley during the war, the series begins in 1952, seven years after the war's end, when Susan, Millie, Lucy, and Jean have returned to their ordinary lives. As the story begins, Susan learns about a series of murders that has occurred in the London area and begins to recognize patterns connecting the killings. This inspires her to return to her codebreaking past, and she reaches out first to Millie, and then to Lucy and Jean, after unsuccessfully trying to convince the police to follow up her theory about the crimes. As they all signed [[Official Secrets Act 1939|orders of secrecy]] about their work during the war, the two married women (Susan and Lucy), disguise their activities from their husbands as a [[Book discussion club|book club]]. Failing to secure police involvement, they move from codebreaking and investigation into the realm of field work, with dangerous consequences on several occasions. Scenes of domestic tranquility are contrasted with scenes of the killer stalking and torturing his victims. While initially skeptical about becoming involved, Millie, Jean, and Lucy are convinced to help Susan once they realize the lives of many women are on the line. The series contrasts the conventional but very different lives of the four women and the sense of usefulness they felt while codebreaking during the war. In the Series 1 finale, the women are forced to confront the man they suspect to be the killer. == Cast and characters == * [[Anna Maxwell Martin]] as Susan Gray *: After her service during the war, Susan became a housewife and the mother of two children after marrying Timothy Gray. She is troubled by the mundanity of her current life. * [[Rachael Stirling]] as Camilla 'Millie' Harcourt *: Millie is an independent-minded single woman, she and Susan lost touch when Susan decided to pursue a more conventional lifestyle. Her room becomes the meeting point for the group. * [[Sophie Rundle]] as Lucy *: Lucy is the youngest member of the circle. She is married to an indolent man named Harry, who beats her when she returns from an investigation. Lucy has an [[eidetic memory]] and specializes in recalling and processing data. * [[Julie Graham]] as Jean McBrian *: Jean, the oldest woman in the circle, was a supervisor of the younger women at Bletchley. A librarian after the war, she has many connections and access to information. * [[Mark Dexter]] as Timothy Gray *: Timothy Gray is a war veteran and the husband of Susan Gray, he is unaware of Susan's service as a codebreaker during the war. * Ed Birch as Harry *: Harry is Lucy's controlling husband, who beat her when he suspected her of infidelity after she was attacked. * [[Michael Gould (actor)|Michael Gould]] as Deputy Commissioner Wainwright *: Also a war veteran, Commissioner Wainwright served with Timothy Gray during the war and now heads the local [[Metropolitan Police]] division. * Simon Sherlock as DCI Compton * [[Simon Williams (actor)|Simon Williams]] as Cavendish *: Cavendish was a high-ranking member of the [[Special Operations Executive]] who helps Susan by providing information from Malcolm Crowley's personnel file. * [[Steven Robertson]] as Malcolm Crowley *: Malcolm Crowley is a disturbed veteran who worked with Cavendish on psychological warfare techniques during the war. * [[Hattie Morahan]] as Alice Merren (series 2) *: Alice, a former Bletchley Park colleague, is awaiting trial for killing John Richards, her old flame and a Bletchley scientist . Jean, believing Alice is covering for someone, begins to reunite the circle to help establish her innocence. * [[Faye Marsay]] as Lizzie Lancaster (series 2) * [[Nick Blood]] as Ben Gladstone (series 2) Lucy’s colleague and love interest ==Episode list== ===Series 1 (2012)=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" width="100%" style="background:#FFFFFF;" !style="background: #bfe0bf;"| # !style="background: #bfe0bf;"| Title !style="background: #bfe0bf;"| Directed by !style="background: #bfe0bf;"| Written by !style="background: #bfe0bf;"| Original air date !style="background: #bfe0bf;"| UK Viewing Figures (millions)
Sourced by [[Broadcasters' Audience Research Board|BARB]]; includes [[ITV HD|ITV1 HD]] and ITV1 +1 |- {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 1 |Title= Cracking a Killer's Code, Part 1 |DirectedBy= [[Andy De Emmony]] |WrittenBy=[[Guy Burt]] |OriginalAirDate= {{start date|2012|9|6|df=y}} |Aux4=5.81 |ShortSummary=Seven years after WWII, four women who worked as codebreakers at Bletchley Park have taken up mundane civilian lives. Susan, now a housewife, has collated data about a series of murders. She tells the police she knows where another body is, but they are unable to locate it and dismiss her. Susan turns to her friends Millie, Lucy, and Jean, former codebreaking colleagues at Bletchley Park. They work out where the next victim will be taken, find the body, then decide only they can find the killer. |LineColor=bfe0bf }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 2 |Title= Cracking a Killer's Code, Part 2 |DirectedBy= Andy De Emmony |WrittenBy= Guy Burt |OriginalAirDate={{start date|2012|9|13|df=y}} |Aux4=5.73 |ShortSummary= The women collate information about the schedules of trains the victims had been on and use the results to identify suspects. Susan gives the police names of three potential perpetrators. Jean and Lucy discover seven similar murders, elsewhere, that the police in those jurisdictions consider solved, but the women believe innocent men have been framed and convicted. The police arrest a man whose name was given to them by Susan, even after she tells them she believes he was framed. The women devise a plan to trap the actual killer using Lucy as bait, but it backfires when she goes with the wrong man. Another suspect emerges from the [[Special Operations Executive]], headed by Cavendish. Susan comes face to face with the killer at a closed mental hospital. |LineColor=bfe0bf }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 3 |Title= Cracking a Killer's Code, Part 3 |DirectedBy=Andy De Emmony |WrittenBy= Guy Burt |OriginalAirDate={{start date|2012|9|20|df=y}} |Aux4=5.37 |ShortSummary= Susan returns with the police, but the killer has gone. She finds a coded message in her home with Cavendish's address, and going there finds him dead. A postcard on Cavendish's desk provides a clue; Susan, following the thread, walks alone into a trap set for her by the killer. |LineColor=bfe0bf }} |} ===Series 2 (2014)=== This series is made up of two 2-part stories totalling four episodes. {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" width="100%" style="background:#FFFFFF;" !style="background: #69E897;"| # !style="background: #69E897;"| Title !style="background: #69E897;"| Directed by !style="background: #69E897;"| Written by !style="background: #69E897;"| Original air date !style="background: #69E897;"| UK Viewing Figures (millions)
Sourced by [[Broadcasters' Audience Research Board|BARB]]; includes [[ITV HD|ITV1 HD]] and ITV1 +1 |- {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 1 |Title= Blood on Their Hands, Part 1 |DirectedBy= Jamie Payne |WrittenBy=Guy Burt |OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2014|1|6|df=y}} |Aux4=5.46 |ShortSummary=Former Bletchley Park colleague Alice Merren ([[Hattie Morahan]]) is awaiting trial for the murder of a distinguished scientist ([[Paul McGann]]). Despite the overwhelming evidence of Alice's guilt, Jean is determined to prove Alice is innocent and reassembles the women to prove it. Their investigation reveals the misguided reason Alice is willing to hang for a crime she did not commit. |LineColor=#69E897 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 2 |Title= Blood on Their Hands, Part 2 |DirectedBy= Jamie Payne |WrittenBy= Guy Burt |OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2014|1|13|df=y}} |Aux4=4.98 |ShortSummary= The circle's investigation discovers three men with chemical burns in a truck crash on Salisbury plain, near the chemical warfare establishment at [[Porton Down]]. They suspect a high level cover-up involving the death of the scientist and the framing of Alice Merren, whereupon they themselves come under surveillance. |LineColor=#69E897 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 3 |Title= Uncustomed Goods, Part 1 |DirectedBy=Sarah Harding |WrittenBy= Guy Burt |OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2014|1|20|df=y}} |Aux4=4.63 |ShortSummary= Due to her notoriety, Alice cannot get a job, so Millie offers help. Millie is involved in the post-war black market. When she disappears, the women must search for her, because the police will not take them seriously. Millie is being held hostage by Soho Maltese gangsters until her shady business partner Jasper ([[Rob Jarvis]]) pays money he owes them. While in captivity, Millie discovers the gangsters are importing Eastern European girls to be sold into prostitution. |LineColor=#69E897 }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 4 |Title= Uncustomed Goods, Part 2 |DirectedBy=Sarah Harding |WrittenBy= Guy Burt |OriginalAirDate= {{Start date|2014|1|27|df=y}} |Aux4=4.66 |ShortSummary= Jasper is murdered, and corruption in the vice squad leads to inaction by the police. The women plot to catch the gang red-handed by buying contraband goods, a ruse that enables Lucy to memorise the gang's encrypted ledger. The women return to Bletchley Park, now a college where Alice's daughter is studying, to take a [[Typex]] machine from the derelict huts, but they instead find an old [[Enigma machine]]. However, they still have to find a way to inform Customs and Excise about the contraband, which includes the trafficked girls. |LineColor=#69E897 }} |} ==Allusions to real events== The premise of the series is based on the women who worked at [[Bletchley Park]] during World War II, who for the most part did not continue in intelligence work, and under the rules of the [[Official Secrets Act 1939]] in the UK never shared the nature of their contributions to crucial aspects of the [[Allies of World War II|Allies]]' victory.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/mavis-batey-bletchley-park-code-breaker-in-world-war-ii-dies-at-92/2013/11/16/ef8682cc-4d49-11e3-9890-a1e0997fb0c0_story.html |title=Mavis Batey, Bletchley Park code breaker in World War II, dies at 92 |date=17 November 2013 |publisher=The Washington Post |author=Emily Langer |accessdate=20 April 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://www.bletchleypark.org.uk/content/hist/ |title=Bletchley Park History |accessdate=20 April 2014 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.warhistoryonline.com/war-articles/wwiis-female-codebreakers.html |title=WWII’s Female Code-breakers in Bletchley Park |date=19 November 2013 |accessdate=20 April 2014 |publisher=War History On Line}}{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-2533366/The-REAL-Bletchley-Circle-Fascinating-work-female-codebreakers-World-War-II-revealed.html |title=The REAL Bletchley Circle: Fascinating work of female codebreakers of World War II revealed |date=13 January 2014 |publisher=Mail Online |author=Ruth Styles |accessdate=20 April 2014 }} In the second series, one character refers to [[sarin#History|sarin]] gas as having been developed by the Germans during World War II, along with other such chemical weapons, then taken up by the former Allies. The UK did have an incident of a young man killed from experiments with the gas in 1953; in 2004, his inquest was reopened, and the cause of death was altered from death by misadventure to death by "application of a nerve agent in a non-therapeutic experiment".{{cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/wiltshire/4013767.stm |publisher=BBC News Online |title=Nerve gas death was 'unlawful' |date=15 November 2004}} ==Reception== Upon its U.S. premiere—which occurred in prime time following U.S. episodes of ''[[Call the Midwife]]'' and ''[[Mr Selfridge]]''—''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' called ''The Bletchley Circle'' "smart, addictive and situated in a fascinating historical moment". In a review of the first series, ''[[The New York Times]]'' said the series finds "a clever, entertaining way to pay tribute to women who in their time were often overlooked and underestimated, and nevertheless found ways to never be ordinary".{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/04/20/arts/television/the-bletchley-circle-on-pbs.html |title=Secret War Heroes, Hiding New Work From Husbands |first=Alessandra |last=Stanley |date=19 April 2013 |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=20 April 2014}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * {{cite web|url=http://www.bletchleyparkresearch.co.uk/the-bletchley-circle-review-did-the-writers-get-it-right/ |title=Did the writers get it right?|website= bletchleyparkresearch.co.uk}} Discussion of the show's historical accuracy ==External links== * {{IMDb title|id=2275990|title=The Bletchley Circle}} * [https://www.pbs.org/program/bletchley-circle/ The Bletchley Circle] at [[PBS]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Bletchley Circle, The}} [[Category:2010s British drama television series]] [[Category:2012 British television programme debuts]] [[Category:2014 British television programme endings]] [[Category:Bletchley Park]] [[Category:British crime television series]] [[Category:English-language television programs]] [[Category:ITV television dramas]] [[Category:Television series by ITV Studios]] [[Category:PBS network shows]] [[Category:Television shows set in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Cryptography in fiction]]

revision.comment: Redirected unsourced and uninformative stub to its author [[Ibn Taymiyyah]]

page.title: The Mistress of the Copper Mountain

revision.comment: /* In The Malachite Box */ fixed link
revision.text:
[[File:Stamps of Russia 2004 No 912-914 crop.jpg|thumb|The Mistress of the Copper Mountain and Tanyushka]] [[File:Coat of Arms of Polevskoy.svg|thumb|The coat of arms of [[Polevskoy]] ''(from left to right)'': the [[Venus symbol]] (♀), which represents the chemical element [[copper]] and was the brand of the [[Polevskoy Copper Smelting Plant]], the Mistress of the Copper Mountain depicted as the golden lizard, and the [[Octagram|eight-pointed]] [[Star (heraldry)|star]], the brand of the [[Seversky Pipe Plant]].]] {{About|a fairy tale character|the fairy tale|The Mistress of the Copper Mountain (fairy tale)}} '''The Mistress of the Copper Mountain''' ({{lang-rus|Хозяйка медной горы|Hozjajka mednoj gory}}), also known as '''The Malachite Maid''', is a legendary creature from [[Slavic mythology]] and a [[Russian fairy tale]] character,{{cite book|editor=V. Lopatin|others=O. Ivanova, I. Nechayeva, L, Cheltsova|title=Russkij orfograficheskij slovar: okolo 180 000 slov |script-title = ru:Русский орфографический словарь: около 180 000 слов |trans-title = Russian orthographic dictionary: about 180 000 words|edition=2|year=2004|publisher=Российская академия наук. Институт русского языка им. В. В. Виноградова|location=Moscow|language=Russian}} the mountain spirit from the legends of the [[Ural (region)|Ural]] miners and the Mistress of the [[Ural Mountains]] of [[Russia]].{{cite book|last=Levkiyevskaya|first=Yelena|authorlink=Yelena Levkiyevskaya|editor=N. I. Tolstoy|others=The [[Russian Academy of Sciences]]|title=Slavyanskie drevnosti. Etnolingvisticheskiy slovar | trans-title = Slavic antiquity. Ethnolinguistic dictionary |script-title = ru:Славянские древности: Этнолингвистический словарь |volume=1|year=1995|publisher=Mezhdunarodnye Otnosheniya|location=Moscow|language=Russian|isbn=978-5-7133-0704-2|pages=520–521|title-link=Slavic antiquity. Ethnolinguistic dictionary}}{{cite book|last=Bezrukova|first=V. S.|title= Osnovy dukhovnoj kultury entsiklopedicheskij slovar pedagoga| trans-title = Bases of Spiritual Culture. The Teacher's Encyclopedic Dictionary|script-title = ru:Основы духовной культуры (энциклопедический словарь педагога) |year=2000 |location=Yekaterinburg|language=Russian}} In the national [[Folklore|folktales]] and legends, she is depicted as an extremely beautiful green-eyed young woman in a [[malachite]] gown or as a [[lizard]] with a crown. She has been viewed as the patroness of [[miner]]s,{{cite book|last=Levkiyevskaya|first=Yelena|authorlink=Yelena Levkiyevskaya|editor=N. I. Tolstoy|others=The [[Russian Academy of Sciences]]|title=Slavyanskie drevnosti. Etnolingvisticheskiy slovar | trans-title = Slavic antiquity. Ethnolinguistic dictionary |script-title = ru:Славянские древности: Этнолингвистический словарь|volume=3|year=2004|publisher=Mezhdunarodnye Otnosheniya|location=Moscow|language=Russian|isbn=978-5-7133-1207-7|pages=245–248 |chapter=Metals|title-link=Slavic antiquity. Ethnolinguistic dictionary}} the protector and owner of hidden underground riches, the one who can either permit or prevent the [[mining]] of stones and metals in certain places. "The Copper Mountain" is the [[Gumyoshevsky mine]], the oldest mine of the Ural Mountains, which was called "The Copper Mountain" or simply "The Mountain" by the populace. It is now located in the town of [[Polevskoy]], [[Sverdlovsk Oblast]]. In some regions of the Ural Mountains, the image of the Mistress is connected with another female creature from the local folktales, the '''[[Azovka|Azov Girl]]''' ({{lang-rus|Азовка|'''Azovka'''}}), the enchanted girl or princess who lives inside [[Mount Azov]].Blazhes 1983, p. 7. The Mistress of the Copper Mountain became a well known character from her appearance in [[Pavel Bazhov]]'s collection of the Ural Mountains folktales (also known as ''[[skaz]]'') called ''[[The Malachite Box]]''. The Mistress appears in the third ''skaz'', "[[The Mistress of the Copper Mountain (fairy tale)|The Mistress of the Copper Mountain]]" and in 9 other stories from the collection, including "[[The Stone Flower]]", "[[List of stories within The Malachite Box#The Manager's Boot-Soles|The Manager's Boot-Soles]]", "[[List of stories within The Malachite Box#Sochen and His Stones|Sochen and His Stones]]". ==Characteristics== The Mistress of the Copper Mountain has the appearance of an extremely beautiful young woman with green eyes. Some of her more distinctive features include dark [[braided hair]], ribbons from thin tinkling [[copper]], and a gown that is made from [[malachite]]. She wears a diadem decorated with malachite and precious stones.{{cite book|title=Soviet Life. Issues 322-327 - Page 30|url=https://books.google.com/?id=J5waAQAAMAAJ&q=Malakhitnitsa&dq=Malakhitnitsa|year=1983|publisher=Embassy of the Union of the Soviet Socialist Republics in the USA}} As a mountain spirit,{{cite book|last1=DeLoughrey|first1=Elizabeth|last2=Didur|first2=Jill|last3=Carrigan|first3=Anthony|title=Global Ecologies and the Environmental Humanities: Postcolonial Approaches|url=https://books.google.com/?id=VpMGCAAAQBAJ&pg=PT273&dq=Mistress+of+the+Copper+Mountain#v=onepage&q=Mistress%20of%20the%20Copper%20Mountain&f=false|series=Routledge Interdisciplinary Perspectives on Literature|date=April 10, 2015|publisher=[[Routledge]]|isbn=9781317574309|chapter=13 Ghost Mountains and Stone Maidens}} she is the protector and owner of hidden underground riches.{{cite journal|last=Svalova|first=Valentina|date=June 10, 2000|title=The history of geothermal resources use in Russia and the former USSR|publisher=[[International Geothermal Association]]|url=http://www.geothermal-energy.org/pdf/IGAstandard/WGC/2000/R0647.PDF}} She is said to be always surrounded by her servants, small [[lizard]]s, which can be green, blue, golden or luminous.Shvabauer 2009, p. 63. The Mistress can appear as a lizard herself.{{cite journal|last=Koreniuk|first=Maria|date=April 2015|title=The Images of Reptiles on the Items Found at the Glyadenovsky Bone Bed|journal=Journal of Siberian Federal University. Humanities & Social Sciences|volume=8|issue=4 |url= http://www.elib.sfu-kras.ru/handle/2311/16760}} According to the legends, a person who sees the Mistress comes under her spell. She shows kindness to good people and skilled craftsmen, helping them to find jewels and gold, but if her conditions aren't met, the person loses all his luck, skill and can even die.Blazhes 1983, p. 9. She could permit or prevent the mining in certain places, give or take wealth. The sacral being, the Mistress was surrounded by rituals and [[taboo]]s, e.g. women did not come down in the mine, because it was the Mistress's domain, and young men seeking her patronage did not marry. The violation of the taboos was supposed to bring a harsh punishment. Children were taught not to shout and quarrel next to the stones, and to keep quiet in the mines, because, according to popular belief, the Maid disliked loud noises.Nikulina 2003, p. 78. Her distinguishing attributes were lizards, copper and malachite. == Other names == The Mistress of the Copper Mountain has many other names, such as The Stone Mother ({{lang-rus|Горная матка|Gornaja matka|links=no}}),Nikulina 2003, p. 77. The Stone Maiden ({{lang-rus|Каменная девка|Kamennaja devka|links=no}}),Bazhov 1952, p. 241. The Serpent Mistress, The Lizard Queen,{{cite book|last1=Richmond|first1=Simon|last2=Elliott|first2=Mark|title=Russia & Belarus|url=https://books.google.com/?id=jcNZUzdd-ukC&pg=PA432&lpg=PA432&dq=%22The+Lizard+Queen%22+copper#v=onepage&q=%22The%20Lizard%20Queen%22%20copper&f=false|edition=4|year=2006|publisher=Lonely Planet Publications|location=Melbourne|isbn=978-1741042917|page=432}} The Mistress of the Copper Mine,{{cite web|url=http://littlewhitecrow.co.uk/1713.php|title=The Malachite Casket: Tales from the Urals – Pavel Bazhov, Alan Moray Williams|publisher=Little White Crow|accessdate=30 November 2015}} The Malachite Girl,{{cite book|last=Bazhov|first=Pavel Petrovich |author2=translated by Alan Moray Williams|title=The Malachite Casket: tales from the Urals|url=https://books.google.ru/books/about/The_malachite_casket.html?id=UD-sAAAAIAAJ|series=Library of selected Soviet literature|year=1944|publisher=[[Hutchinson (publisher)|Hutchinson & Co. ltd.]]|location=The University of California |page= 25}} The Malachite MaidBazhov 1950s, p. 14. or The Malachite Lady ({{lang-rus|Малахитница|Malakhitnitsa|links=no}}). The miners simply called her "Herself". ===The Azov Girl=== In many national folktales, the Mistress and [[Azovka]] (lit. "the Azov Girl") are identical with each other,Blazhes 1983, p. 10. and the same stories are told about each of them. The tales about Azovka are very different from one another, although they share some common characteristics. Firstly, that there's a cave with hidden treasures inside [[Mount Azov]]. Secondly, few people found the cave, and no one could get the treasures. The treasures belong to the Tatars, the [[Bashkirs]], or "the Old People".{{cite web|url=http://bibliogid.ru/krug-chteniya/mify-legendy-narodnye-skazki/1019-bazhov-p-p-malakhitovaya-shkatulka|title=Bazhov P. P. The Malachite Box|date=13 May 2006|publisher=Bibliogid|language=Russian|accessdate=25 November 2015}} According to popular belief, Azovka lives/is held captive inside the cave (or the mountain), and she guards the treasures. In most tales, she is the enchanted girl, possibly stolen by the [[Tatars]], the cursed Tatar princess, the Old People's queen or their elder's daughter.Shvabauer 2009, p. 113.Blazhes 1983, p. 8. == Appearances == === In ''The Malachite Box'' === The Mistress of the Copper Mountain appears in the third [[Pavel Bazhov]]'s ''skaz'' from ''The Malachite Box'', "[[The Mistress of the Copper Mountain (fairy tale)|The Mistress of the Copper Mountain]]", first published in the 11th issue of ''Krasnaya Nov'' in 1936;{{cite book|last=Bazhov|first=Pavel|authorlink=Pavel Bazhov|title=Works. In Three Volumes |volume=1|date=1976|publisher=[[Pravda (publisher)|Pravda]]|location=Moscow|language=Russian |page=342}} and then in many other tales: "[[The Malachite Casket (fairy tale)|The Malachite Casket]]", "[[The Stone Flower]]", "[[List of stories within The Malachite Box#The Manager's Boot-Soles|The Manager's Boot-Soles]]", "[[List of stories within The Malachite Box#Sochen and His Stones|Sochen and His Stones]]", "[[The Malachite Box#The Master Craftsman|The Master Craftsman]]", "[[List of stories within The Malachite Box#The Two Lizards|The Two Lizards]]", "[[List of stories within The Malachite Box#A Fragile Twig|A Fragile Twig]]", "[[List of stories within The Malachite Box#The Grass Hideaway|The Grass Hideaway]]", and "[[List of stories within The Malachite Box#Tayutka's Mirror|Tayutka's Mirror]]".{{cite web|url=http://fantlab.ru/work89037|title=Уральские сказы|publisher=[[FantLab]]|language=Russian|accessdate=1 December 2015|trans-title = Tales from the Urals }}Bazhov 1952, p. 242. Bazhov confirmed that he based the character on local legends. He said: "Yes, I believe that the series of tales connected with the Gumyoshevsky mine is closer to folklore. In my opinion, they represent the attempt to reconstruct the folklore of this mine". When asked whether the character from his writing differs from its folklore interpretation, Bazhov replied: "I don't believe there is a difference. If there is, it is bad [news]".Mironov, A. "''Obraz Hozjajki Mednoj gory v skazah P. P. Bazhova'' Образ Хозяйки Медной горы в сказах П. П. Бажова [The character of the Mistress of the Copper Mountain in P. P. Bazhov's tales]" in: ''P. P. Bazhov i socialisticheskij realizm.'' In "[[The Mistress of the Copper Mountain (fairy tale)|The Mistress of the Copper Mountain]]" she is described as follows:
You could see from her plait she was a maid. It was a sort of deep black, that plait of hers, and didn't dangle as our maids' do, but lay close and straight down her back. And the ribbons at the end weren't quite red and weren't quite green, they'd something of both. You could see the light shining through them and they seemed to click a little, like thin leaves of copper. [...] She was not very tall, with a pretty figure, and she was a real fidget - couldn't sit still a minute. [...] Her robe, now, it was something you'd never see anywhere else. It was all made of silk malachite, that's a kind you get sometimes. It's stone but it looks like silk, you want to take and stroke it.Bazhov 1950s, p. 12.
In "[[The Stone Flower]]" it's said that the Mistress has her own "mountain craftsmen":
They're skilful craftsmen who live in the mountain, and no man ever sees them. Whatever the Mistress wants, they make it for her. I saw a bit of their work once. [...] Our serpents, no matter how good they are, they're but stone, but this was like as if it was living. A black line down the black, and eyes—ye'd think it was just going to up and sting ye. They can make anything!Bazhov 1950s, pp. 61–62.
In "The Manager's Boot-Soles" it's said that the Mistress "didn't like it when folks were treated ill underground".Bazhov 1950s, pp. 112. She appears before the cruel bailiff:
All of a sudden the bailiff saw a figure in front of him. It was moving lightly, waving a lamp. At the turn of the gallery he saw it was a woman. [...] He started running after her, but his faithful men weren't in any great hurry to follow. They were all shaking. Because they saw this was bad — it was ''she'' herself. [...] The bailiff saw a maid of amazing beauty standing before him, and here brows were drawn together in a line and her eyes blazed like burning coals.Bazhov 1950s, pp. 114–115.
In ''The Malachite Box'', she serves as a "magic helper" to the characters.Balina 2013, p. 269. "It's a chancy thing to meet her, it brings woe for a bad man".Bazhov 1950s, p. 20. She can be reached through the stone forest.Shvabauer 2009, p. 146. She is cruel and just, she dislikes greedy people and is indifferent toward their suffering, but she shows her benevolent side to those with talent and selflessness.Meshcherova 2014, p. 33. [[Valentin Blazhes]] stated that in ''the Malachite Box'' she is a classical [[ambivalence|ambivalent]] character, because she combines good and evil, life and death, beauty and ugliness. Nataliya Shvabauer commented that her duality is represented in her every trait, from the appearance to her functions. Even her jokes can be deadly, as evident from "Sochen and His Stones". ===In other media=== The character Queen of the Copper Mountain appeared in [[Mercedes Lackey]]'s 2007 novel ''[[Fortune's Fool (novel)|Fortune's Fool]]''.{{cite web|url=http://kniga.ompural.ru/content.php?main=kniga_life&id=100003|title=The Malachite Box|publisher=The Live Book Museum. Yekaterinburg.|language=Russian|accessdate=22 November 2015}} [[Shimun Vrochek]] authored a story called ''The Master of the Copper Mountain'' ({{lang-rus|Хозяин Медной горы|Hozjain Mednoj gory|links=no}}), in which he mentioned the character. It was published in his ''Serzhantu Nikto Ne Zvonit'' collection in 2006.{{cite book|last=Vrochek|first=Shimun|authorlink=Shimun Vrochek|title=The Master of the Copper Mountain |script-title = ru:Хозяин Медной горы | trans-title =Hozjain Mednoj gory|url=https://books.google.com/?id=B55O9EPPTFkC&pg=PA4&dq=%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%B7%D1%8F%D0%B8%D0%BD+%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9+%D0%B3%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%8B#v=onepage&q=%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%B7%D1%8F%D0%B8%D0%BD%20%D0%BC%D0%B5%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9%20%D0%B3%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%8B&f=false|series=Рассказ из авторского сборника «Сержанту никто не звонит», 2006 г.|year=2015|publisher=Litres|isbn=9785457312203}} [[Vladimir Makanin]] writes the Mistress parody characters in some of his stories, such as the mother of the character Kolka in his 1976 short story "Voices" ({{lang-rus|Голоса|Golosa|links=no}}). == Origin and development == [[File:Coat of Arms of Sverdlovsk (Sverdlovsk oblast) (1973).svg|thumb|The Lizard Queen ''(on the right)'' in the old [[Yekaterinburg|Sverdlovsk]] coat of arms (1973).]] [[File:Sysert coat of arms 1982.gif|thumb|The Lizard Queen ''(on the right)'' in the old [[Sysert]] coat of arms (1982).]] Pavel Bazhov had heard the tales about her at the [[Polevskoy Copper Smelting Plant]] from the miners' storyteller Vasily Hmelinin ({{lang-rus|Василий Хмелинин|links=no}}), nicknamed "Grandpa Slyshko" by children. "The Copper Mountain" is believed to be the [[Gumyoshevsky mine]], the oldest mine of the Ural Mountains. It was sometimes called "The Copper Mountain" or simply "The Mountain" by the populace.{{cite journal|last=Bazhov|first=Pavel|year=1939|title=Foreword to the Skazy|journal=[[Oktyabr (magazine)|Oktyabr]]|issue=5–6|page=158|issn=0132-0637|language=Russian}} [[Valery Dyomin]] commented that the Mistress is a universal [[mytheme]], while the Copper mountain is the specific location: the Gumyoshevsky mine and [[Mount Azov]].{{cite journal|last=Kulikova|first=E. V|year=2012|title=От литературного табу к Хозяйке Медной горы: деконструкция мифа в прозе В. Маканина |trans-title = From a literary taboo to the Mistress of the Copper Mountain: the myth deconstruction in V. Makanin's prose|script-title= ''Ot literaturnogo tabu k Hozjajke Mednoj gory: dekonstruktsija mifa v proze V. Makanina'' |journal=Molodoy Ucheny|volume=7|issue=42|pages=161–164|issn=2072-0297|url=http://www.moluch.ru/archive/42/5127/|language=Russian}} The origin of the character is unclear. A concept of a [[mother goddess]] or [[Mat Zemlya|Mother Earth]] was very popular in every culture, including the local [[Mansi people|Mansi]] and [[Khanty people]]. The Ural ethnographer A. Sagalayev suggested that the character originated from the goddesses [[Umay]] and [[Kaltes-Ekwa]]. He noted that the figure of a mother goddess in people's perception sometimes shrinks to the size of a rock and a sculpture or expands to the size of a mountain. The Mistress might have appeared as a successor of Azovka, because she was most famous in the same areas as Azovka before her, so the keeper of treasures slowly turned into their master.Shvabauer 2009, p. 147. Bazhov believed that the most ancient creature of the Ural mythology was in fact Azovka, [[the Great Serpent]] appeared next, and the last one was the Mistress. Just like Azovka, the Malachite Maid attracts single men.Shvabauer 2009, p. 153. Mark Lipovetsky commented her black hair colour hints at her non-Slavic parentage, possibly from the "Old People", like Azovka. Dark-haired and mysterious, she does not look like typical Russian girls.Meshcherova 2014, p. 32. Bazhov believed that miners simply missed women, because their work allowed for little contact with them.{{cite journal|last=Zherdev|first=Denis|year=2003 |title= Binarnost kak element pojetiki bazhovskikh skazov |script-title = ru:Бинарность как элемент поэтики бажовских сказов |journal=Izvestiya of the Ural State University|issue=28 |pages=46–57|url= http://elar.urfu.ru/bitstream/10995/24181/1/iurg-2003-28-06.pdf|language=Russian |trans-title = Binarity as the Poetic Element in Bazhov's Skazy}} He also thought that the Mistress outgrew her initial function of a treasure keeper. She became "the embodiment of power, wealth and beauty" which revealed itself only before the best of people.{{cite book|last=Bazhov|first=Pavel|title=У старого рудника |trans-title = By the Old Mine|url=https://books.google.ru/books?id=Hmp6b9Ugq2MC&dq|series=The Malachite Casket: Tales from the Urals|date=2014-07-10|publisher=Litres|language=Russian|isbn=9785457073548}} E. Kulikova theorized that her place in the Ural mythology is most likely connected with the perception of the mountains as "magical space". The mountain was the source of life, the protector from hostile forces and the residence of divine patrons. [[Alexei Ivanov (writer)|Alexei Ivanov]] suggested that the Mistress most likely originates from a [[spirit of place]] as a "stone [[dryad]]".{{cite journal|last=Ivanov|first=Alexei|year=2004 |trans-title = The Ugrian Archetype in the Demonology of Bazhov's Stories |title=Угорский архетип в демонологии сказов Бажова|journal=The Philologist|issue=5|issn=2076-4154|url=http://philolog.pspu.ru/module/magazine/do/mpub_5_90}} There is also a hypothesis that she repsesents the Roman goddess [[Venus (mythology)|Venus]], as local copper from the [[Polevskoy Copper Smelting Plant]] was branded with the [[Venus symbol]] (♀) for tens of years in the 18th century.{{cite book|last=Perfilyev|first=A.|title=Полевской край: Историко-краеведческий сборник |trans-title = Polevskoy region: the local history|url=http://www.polevskoylife.ru/e/410097-gerb-i-simvolyi-polevskogo|edition=1|volume=3|year=1998|publisher=Uraltreid|language=Russian|chapter=Герб и символы Полевского}} V. Bezrukova theorizes that the Mistress of the Copper Mountain symbolizes the "relationship" between people and the mountain riches, and that she in fact protects [[Christian virtues]], e.g. she prevents greed, encourages kindness, modesty, honor and skill (Christian virtues). However Alexei Ivanov argues that she reveals her "genetic relationship" with [[pagan god]]s, and her ethics is not Christian. In one of the stories she takes the gold out of the mine after a church is built nearby.Shvabauer 2009, p. 150. Maya Nikulina points at her relation to the [[realm of the dead]], as she does not ear or drink, does not leave any traces, her clothing is made of stone and so on, and the Mountain connects her to the world of the living. The character might be of [[Finno-Ugric peoples|Finno-Ugric]] origin.{{cite web|url=http://www.ulc-russia.com/fun/people_talk/item/91/|title=Translations From Pavel Bazhov into English. Part 1|last=Vernikov|first=Alexander|publisher=ULC: Ural Life & Culture|accessdate=23 December 2015}} The Finno-Ugric peoples, who lived in that area, later migrated to the [[Baltic Sea]] or assimilated into the new Russian culture. Their folklore featured the underground riches, moral and spiritual powers, impersonated in [[Chthonic]] deities, mining and metallurgic techniques unknown to Russians. The Mistress's attributes—lizards, copper and malachite—are not Christian. Nataliya Shvabauer commented that the lizards are foul supernatural creatures.Shvabauer 2009, p. 149. The images of lizards and snakes were found on the [[Permian bronze casts]] (the 5-15 centuries) around [[Mount Azov]]. Copper was a symbol of female beauty at the Urals. Malachite symbolized youth, hope, misfortune and grief at the same time.{{cite journal|last=Prikazchikova|first=Yelena|year=2003 |trans-title = The Stone Force of The Ural Copper Mountains|title= Kamennaja sila mednykh gor Urala|script-title = ru:Каменная сила медных гор Урала|journal=Izvestiya of the Ural State University|volume=28|pages=11–23|language=Russian |url=http://elar.urfu.ru/bitstream/10995/24166/1/iurg-2003-28-02.pdf}} The craftsmen who worked with malachite often died of [[tuberculosis]], affected by the poisonous malachite dust. The [[gemcutter]]s produced malachite jewellery for sale only, but never wore it themselves. Keeping it in the house was a bad [[omen]]. == Reception == The Mistress became a popular character in the Soviet Union. The [[Folkloristics|folklorists]] of [[the Ural State University]], who collected tales near [[Sysert]] after Pavel Bazhov's death, noted they "have not met a single person who did not hear about the Mistress", but they mostly knew about her from Bazhov's ''skazy'' and referred to them: "Read some Bazhov, he wrote it down". Few story-tellers heard of her from [[oral tradition]]. During Soviet times critics commonly described this character as the protector of the working class from the oppressors. Maya Nikulina argued that the Mistress is neither the rescuer nor the protector. Rather than defending the workers, she tests them. Social justice is of no concern to her: "the landlord is punished for being greedy and stupid", not for being the landlord.Nikulina 2003, p. 80. Mark Lipovetsky commented that she is the most terrifying characters of the collection, a beautiful girl and a dangerous demonic creature at the same time.Lipovetsky 2014, p. 217. He believed that she represents the struggle and unity between [[Eros and Thanatos]],Lipovetsky 2014, p. 220. and that she is characterized by three major Freudian motives—the [[Libido|sexual drive]], the [[death drive]] (her realm is the realm of the dead) and the [[castration anxiety]] (loss of power). The latter is shown when she persistently and spitefully provokes the local administration, forcing the protagonists ("The Mistress of the Copper Mountain", "The Two Lizards") to relay offensive messages.Lipovetsky 2014, p. 222–223. Denis Zherdev pointed out that the Mistress's female domain is the world of chaos, destruction or spontaneous uncontrolled acts of creation. Colliding with the ordered factory world, such power brings in randomness, variability, unpredictability and capriciousness. Direct contact with it is a violation of world order, and does not end well.{{cite web|url=http://mith.ru/alb/lib/bazov/mim2_1.htm|title=Poetika skazov Bazhova |script-title = ru:Поэтика сказов Бажова| trans-title =The poetics of Bazhov's stories|last=Zherdev|first=Denis|publisher=Research Library Mif.Ru|language=Russian|accessdate=14 December 2015}} The author of ''The Fairy Tale Encyclopedia'' suggests that the Mistress represents the conflict between human kind and nature. She compares the character with [[Mephistopheles]], because a human needs to [[Deal with the Devil|wager his soul]] with her in order to get the ultimate knowledge, however, the Mistress does not force anyone to abandon their moral values, and therefore "is not painted in dark colours".{{cite book|last=Budur|first=Naralya|title=The Fairy Tale Encyclopedia|url=https://books.google.com/?id=_X49ywrpGS8C|year=2005|publisher=Olma Media Group|language=Russian|isbn=9785224048182|page=285|chapter=The Mistress of the Copper Mountain}} Lyudmila Skorino believed that she represented the nature of the Urals, which inspires a creative person with its beauty.Bazhov 1952, p. 232. == References == {{Reflist|2}} == Sources == * {{cite book|last=Blazhes|first=Valentin |authorlink=Valentin Blazhes|title= Bytovanie folklora v sovremennosti, na materiale jekspedicij 60-80 godov|script-title = ru:Бытование фольклора в современности, на материале экспедиций 60-80 годов|url=http://elar.urfu.ru/bitstream/10995/19386/1/fu7-1983-02.pdf|series=Фольклор Урала|volume=7|year=1983|publisher=[[The Ural State University]]|location=Sverdlovsk|language=Russian|pages=5–22|chapter=Рабочие предания родины П. П. Бажова |trans-title= The existence of folklore nowadays, based on the material of the 60-80s expeditions}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.lib.csu.ru/texts/DISS/001318.pdf|title=Tipologija fantasticheskih personazhej v folklore gornorabochih Zapadnoj Evropy i Rossii |script-title = ru:Типология фантастических персонажей в фольклоре горнорабочих Западной Европы и России|last=Shvabauer|first=Nataliya|date=10 January 2009|website=Dissertation|publisher=The Ural State University |language=Russian|accessdate=25 November 2015|trans-title = The Typology of the Fantastic Characters in the Miners' Folklore of Western Europe and Russia}} * {{cite journal|last=Lipovetsky|first=Mark |year=2014|title=The Uncanny in Bazhov's Tales|journal=Quaestio Rossica|volume=2|issue=2 |pages=212–230|issn=2311-911X|doi=10.15826/qr.2014.2.051|language=Russian |url=http://journals.urfu.ru/index.php/QR/article/view/051}} * {{cite book|last=Bazhov|first=Pavel|authorlink=Pavel Bazhov|editor=Valentina Bazhova |editor2=[[Alexey Surkov]] |editor3=Yevgeny Permyak|title= Sobranie sochinenij v trekh tomakh|trans-title= Works. In Three Volumes|script-title = ru:Собрание сочинений в трех томах |volume=1|year=1952|publisher=[[Khudozhestvennaya Literatura]]|location=Moscow|language=Russian}} * {{cite book|last=Bazhov|first=Pavel | author2=translated by Eve Manning|title=Malachite Casket: Tales from the Urals|url=http://issuu.com/uralmap/docs/bazhov_pavel_malachite_casket_tales|publisher=Foreign Languages Publishing House|location=Moscow | year=1950s}} * {{cite journal|last=Meshcherova|first=K.| author2=Gerasimova A.|date=20 June 2014|title= Legendy i mify Urala glazami khudozhnikov|script-title = ru:Легенды и мифы Урала глазами художников|journal=Materials Collection of the 5th International Scientific Conference|trans-title = Legends and Myths of the Urals by the Eyes of the Artists|issue=''Nauchnye diskussii o tsennostjah sovremennogo obshhestva'' [Научные дискуссии о ценностях современного общества], lit. "Scientific discussions about our society's values"|url=http://m.aksioma-conf.ru/files/СБОРНИК,%20НД-5.pdf#page=31|language=Russian}} * {{cite journal|last=Nikulina|first=Maya|year=2003|title= Pro zemelnye dela i pro tajnuju silu. O dalnikh istokakh uralskoj mifologii P.P. Bazhova|script-title = ru:Про земельные дела и про тайную силу. О дальних истоках уральской мифологии П.П. Бажова |trans-title = Of land and the secret force. The distant sources of P.P. Bazhov's Ural mythology |journal=Filologichesky Klass|volume=9|url=http://cyberleninka.ru/article/n/pro-zemelnye-dela-i-pro-taynuyu-silu-o-dalnih-istokah-uralskoy-mifologii-p-p-bazhova|language=Russian}} * {{cite book|last1=Balina|first1=Marina|last2=Rudova|first2=Larissa|title=Russian Children's Literature and Culture|url= https://books.google.ru/books?id=njCJHBRVYU8C |series=Literary Criticism|date=1 February 2013|publisher=[[Routledge]]|isbn=978-1135865566}} * {{cite book |title=P. Бажова в меняющемся мире | trans-title = Pavel Bazhov and socialist realism // The works of Pavel Bazhov in the changing world|url=http://gigabaza.ru/doc/95681.html|series=The materials of the inter-university research conference devoted to the 125th birthday|date=28–29 January 2004|publisher=The [[Ural State University]]|location=Yekaterinburg|language=Russian|pages=18–26 }} == See also == * [[Karzełek]] * [[Shubin (ghost)]] * [[The Fire-Fairy]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Mistress of the Copper Mountain, The}} [[Category:Slavic tutelary deities]] [[Category:Russian folklore characters]] [[Category:Mythic humanoids]] [[Category:Fictional lizards]] [[Category:Female legendary creatures]] [[Category:Mining in folklore]] [[Category:Fictional characters with earth or stone abilities]] [[Category:Russian mythology]] [[Category:Female characters in fairy tales]] [[Category:Legendary serpents]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 1936]] [[Category:Mythological queens]] [[Category:Slavic legendary creatures]]

{{about|the film|the television miniseries of the same name|The Singing Detective}} {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = The Singing Detective | image = The Singing Detective.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Keith Gordon]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * [[Bruce Davey]] * [[Mel Gibson]] * Steven Saxton * Steven Haft}} | screenplay = [[Dennis Potter]] | based on = {{based on|''[[The Singing Detective]]''|Dennis Potter}} <!-- LINK ONCE IN INFOBOX --> | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Robert Downey Jr.]] * [[Robin Wright|Robin Wright Penn]] * [[Jeremy Northam]] * [[Katie Holmes]] * Mel Gibson}} | music = [[Basil Poledouris]] | cinematography = [[Tom Richmond (cinematographer)|Tom Richmond]] | editing = Jeff Wishengrad | studio = [[Icon Productions]] | distributor = [[Paramount Vantage|Paramount Classics]] | released = {{Film date|2003|01|17|[[2003 Sundance Film Festival]]|2003|10|24|United States}} | runtime = 109 minutes<!--Theatrical runtime: 108:51--><ref>{{cite web | title=''THE SINGING DETECTIVE'' (15) | url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/AFF188850/ | publisher=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=October 2, 2003 | accessdate=June 14, 2012}}</ref> | country = United States | language = English | budget = $8 million<ref name=IMDB>{{cite web|title=The Singing Detective (2003) - Box office / business|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0314676/business|publisher=[[IMDb|Internet Movie Database]]|accessdate=14 June 2012}}</ref> | gross = $337,174<ref name=BOM>{{cite web|title=The Singing Detective (2003)|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=singingdetective.htm|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=14 June 2012}}</ref> }} '''''The Singing Detective''''' is a 2003 American [[Musical film|musical]] [[Crime film|crime]] [[comedy film]] directed by [[Keith Gordon]] and loosely based on the [[The Singing Detective|BBC serial of the same name]], a work by British writer [[Dennis Potter]]. It stars [[Robert Downey Jr.]] and features a supporting cast that includes [[Katie Holmes]], [[Adrien Brody]], [[Robin Wright|Robin Wright Penn]], and [[Mel Gibson]], as well as a number of songs from the 1950s.
==Plot== Suffering from the skin disease [[psoriasis]] and crippling [[psoriatic arthritis]], [[detective]] novelist Dan Dark is in such pain in a hospital that he begins to delve into fantasy, resulting in several storylines told simultaneously: * A [[film noir]] based on Dark's novel, ''The Singing Detective'', in which a [[nightclub act|nightclub singer]]/private eye, hired by Mark Binney, takes on a strange case involving prostitutes and two mysterious men. Nothing is ever solved from this, only a vague plot. Notably, all of the people in the film noir are played by people who are real people in Dark's life; for example, Dark's nurse plays a singer. * The present reality, in which Dark is tormented by incredible pain. Dark interacts with the various people around him, as the doctors and nurses attempt to help, but are dismissed by Dark's anger and bitterness towards everyone. His sense of reality then collapses into hallucinations as the people randomly sing choreographed musical numbers, such as "How Much Is That Doggie In The Window?" In the end, his reality is blended with the film noir and he is abducted by the two mysterious men, only to be shot by the titular "singing detective". * Dark's traumatic childhood in the past, which explains Dark's repulsion toward sexuality (Dark had watched his mother have sex with other men, including his father's business partner), and his own fiery temper.
==Cast== {{div col}} * [[Robert Downey Jr.]] as Dan Dark ** [[David Dorfman]] as young Dan Dark * [[Robin Wright|Robin Wright Penn]] as Nicola / Nina / Blonde * [[Jeremy Northam]] as Mark Binney * [[Katie Holmes]] as Nurse Mills * [[Mel Gibson]] as Dr. Gibbon * [[Adrien Brody]] as First Hood * [[Jon Polito]] as Second Hood * [[Carla Gugino]] as Betty Dark / Hooker * [[Saul Rubinek]] as Skin Specialist * [[Alfre Woodard]] as Chief of Staff * [[Amy Aquino]] as Nurse Nozhki * [[Eddie Jones (actor)|Eddie Jones]] as Moonglow Bartender * [[Clyde Kusatsu]] as Visiting Japanese Doctor {{div col end}}
==Production== Potter's screenplay had been circulating in Hollywood for many years as Potter was enthusiastic about a film version. [[Robert Altman]] was at one time attached to direct with [[Dustin Hoffman]] in the lead, but financing proved difficult and the production was shelved. It was eventually discovered by an executive at [[Mel Gibson]]'s production company [[Icon Productions]], who loved it and got Gibson on board to produce. The screenplay had also been imagined as a [[horror film]] directed by genre veteran [[David Cronenberg]] and starring [[Al Pacino]] as the title character.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0314676/trivia|title=The Singing Detective|date=November 14, 2003|publisher=|via=IMDb}}</ref>
==Reception== The film scored a 39% "Rotten" rating on [[Rotten Tomatoes]], with the consensus being 'Delightful performance from Robert Downey Jr. can't save ''The Singing Detective'''s transition from TV to the big screen'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/singing_detective/|title=The Singing Detective|publisher=}}</ref> While some critics, such as [[Roger Ebert]], liked the film, others, like Joe Baltake at the ''[[Sacramento Bee]]'', considered it an "interesting failure".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/singing_detective/|title=The Singing Detective|publisher=}}</ref>
